Looks on the outside are really important, but not as important as the cabin experience, because this is where you will be spending a lot of the time, and this is also where the Brezza, triumphs over the Venue. And it all starts with the seats itself. They are large, they are supportive. They are very comfortable. Also the dashboard, it sits higher. It's wider, so you get the sense of driving something big. Lots of hard plastics being used everywhere. Scratchy hard plastics; now both the cars get those. But then again the quality here in the Venue feels a grade lower than what the Brezza has to offer. So, this is a slightly smaller, slightly complicated cabin to live with. Now talking about the features, it covers the basics. So you get a really responsive high definition screen. With your modern smartphone connectivity. You get a single pane sunroof. You get you automatic climate control. You also get wireless charging. Everything that the Brezza gets, except... those segment first features. And what the Venue offers over and above the Brezza, or basically what the Brezza doesn't get, that the Venue gets, is that integrated air purifier with the central armrest, which is quite cool. Alright, erase all of that fluff, because now that I've got myself into a really good driving position, thanks to these "electronically adjusted" driving seats, it's time to fire up, the better of the two engines. Because you don't have to worry about your left foot. You can just rest your left foot. And also you don't have to shell a million bucks to get yourself a good automatic transmission. But, when you're driving out here, when you're driving enthusiastically, this tends... to just not the driving thrills. It lags. It's not fun though. (music) Quite raspy, the way it sounds as well. And the steering wheel might be light in the city, but out on the highway, it does really weigh up. And that makes it quite an enthusiastic car. Not an M5. It's not a twin turbo charged V8. But then again for the money that you spent... it is quite good. There are 3 things that are made evidently clear when you start driving the Maruti Suzuki Brezza. Number 1, it lacks power. It is fine till about the speeds of 40, but then after that... it runs out of breath, as if it has cholesterol. It really takes a lot of effort to get this thing moving. Number 2, the ride is phenomenal! It is just brilliant! It is great, it is... It is unbelievable! I mean you can throw anything at it and the suspension will sort you out. And that list can even include speed breakers. And number 3. Everything touch point that involves human interaction has been smoothened out. It's peaceful enough to a level that it's hard to believe that it's a machine that you are operating! Like for instance that engine is super silky smooth. As a result of this, the pedals have zero vibration and they are very well strung. And then the clutch is very light, the bite point is very well refined. And the gearbox, the slots, the gates, everything is just brilliant! It feels like this gearbox deserves to be in a sports car. And no, I'm not making this up. This is actually the reason why you still love driving manual transmission. So the gearbox is a lot of fun to operate. The only thing that the Brezza then lacks is power. And what a shame that is. Because power was never really a concern with the earlier Brezzas. The diesel was. But the earlier Brezza, the petrol powered Brezza, it never felt so underpowered like how this one feels. Now while the Brezza might have lost all that performance, it has definitely earned a lot more fuel efficiency. Yep, this is one of the most efficient petrol powered compact SUV that our market currently has. And yes, I've been driving it like a maniac since the morning, and all of that verifies, it checks. Cause this thing has been throwing some unreal fuel efficiency figures at me! So then this power-train combined with that gimmicky mild-hybrid system, does not make you want to miss that diesel Brezza that we all used to love and adore for its fuel efficiency. Especially this one does the job equally well, while being a lot more refined and while being pollution compliant as well. So I think it's a win-win situation for most of us out there. Alright, this one has been really difficult, but now it's time to sum it up all together. Which of these two should you consider? Which one would we buy happily, as Indians? Well I believe the answer to that question lies in that question itself. No? You don't agree? Well think of it this way... While it was the Venue that really made me smile and I really did enjoy, this compact little SUV with that punchy turbo charged engine, I've come to realise that occasions like these, where you drive in a spirited fashion, present themselves very rare. For normal drivers, normal road users, are going to find themselves either in traffic, or in pothole ridden roads, and that is where, it is the Brezza that feels a lot more rewarding. It is also a lot larger than a Venue. Offers a lot more features than a Venue. So I think it deserves to take that crown. So that extra money that you paid to get yourself this Suzuki badge, not only gets you all those features, it also gets you a peace of mind, and ease of ownership. Ladies and Gentlemen... this is then... the winner of today's comparison. Well, all hail the King! My Lord, you really are great!
